Nguyễn Thị T., age 27, is requesting a 6,944,000 VND loan to support her furniture making business.

Đỗ Thị

loans.use: To purchase additional raw materials to expand product offerings

loans.name: Dem

texts.en: Dem S., 46, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She sells palm juice for an income of about $2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of around $1.50 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a new motorbike

texts.en: Ouch O., 47, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She and her husband buy fish to resell for an income of approximately $3 each per day.  O. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase more fish to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy more fish to resell

texts.en: Song N., 46, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of about $3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of around $5 per day.  N. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

loans.name: Soth

texts.en: Soth P., 28, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-Angkorean Temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk to sell for an income of  about $2 per day. Her husband produces cow ties, earning an income of around $2 per day.  P. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en:
Chhun S., 39, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 2 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ngô's Group

texts.en:
Vỹ  Ngô Thị, age 48, lives in the town of Huyện Yên Phong-tỉnh Bắc Ninh. Vỹ  is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Đông Mai 2 nhóm 06 (Nhóm 06).
 
Vỹ  is married and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, Vỹ  owns and operates a manufacturing business. She manufactures and sells wood products to local businesses and community members. Vỹ  has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000,000 VND a month from these activities.
  
Vỹ  joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities.     She is now requesting a loan of 5,152,000 VND, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. The loan will be the first loan she has taken out from SEDA. Vỹ plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About the other borrowers in the group:

Nguyễn Thị T., age 48, is requesting a 6,944,000 VND loan to support her furniture making business.

Nghiêm Thị P., age 24, is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her furniture making business.

Trần Thị H., age 20, is requesting a 5,152,000 VND loan to support her furniture making business.

loans.name: Anualitte

texts.en:
Annualite is a hard-working 24-year-old married mother of one child. She has a shop in the market that contains new clothes for children and adults and a few pairs of shoes. She has been in this business for 4 years. Annualite’s husband sells second-hand clothes in the market. With this loan, she wishes to buy more new clothes to sell. She hopes that the profits of the business will enable her to buy a piece of land on which she could build a house. 

About the bank:
Urwego Opportunity Bank (UOB) is a public limited company established to provide financial services as a ladder of opportunity to the poor and small entrepreneurs for whom access to formal financial capital is currently limited. UOB's vision is to be a sustainable financial institution achieving significant economic, social and spiritual transformational impact on the underprivileged of Rwanda through a variety of products and related training in a way that reflects the love of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: Purchasing more clothes

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Un S., 31, is married and lives with her husband and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for its pre-Angkorean temples. She weaves Cambodian traditional silk for an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase raw silk to produce more silk products to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy raw silk to produce more silk products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Odette

texts.en:
Odette is 31 years old and her children are 12, 9 and 7 years old. She sells charcoal, both wholesale and retail, and has been running this business since 2001.  Her husband buys overstock items, such as shoes and clothing, and sells them in the market.  With this loan, Odette hopes to buy a bigger piece of land from which she will get trees to burn and have charcoal.  With the profits, she hopes to renovate her house.

About the bank:
Urwego Opportunity Bank (UOB) is a public limited company established to provide financial services as a ladder of opportunity to the poor and small entrepreneurs for whom access to formal financial capital is currently limited. UOB's vision is to be a sustainable financial institution achieving significant economic, social and spiritual transformational impact on the underprivileged of Rwanda through a variety of products and related training in a way that reflects the love of Jesus Christ.

loans.use: To buy land with trees to burn to make charcoal.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia D. C., age 43, is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Amelia owns and operates a clothing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing clothing alteration services to local community members. Amelia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,200 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Amelia joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Amelia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional equipment and tools such as needles and threads. Amelia is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Amelia from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Svay

texts.en:
Mrs. Svay S., 44, is a hard-working woman who tries to earn money by fishing along the river. She has another earner in her husband, shown on the left in the photo, who works in the construction field. They have seven children and almost all of them are working at different jobs.

The coming fishing season is good for fishing but Svay S. doesn’t have enough equipment to fish. Thus, she decided to seek a loan to purchase a net and trap to use in her fishing activity.

loans.use: To purchase a net and trap to use for fishing

loans.name: Drissa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Drissa Sidibé est un homme marié de 29 ans et père de 1 enfant qui vit avec sa femme et son enfant  chez son père  à Bougouni dans le quartier Dougounina de Bougouni.
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 6ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), il décida de partir en aventure, à la recherche d’une vie meilleure.
Ses ambitions n’ont pas été réalisées, alors il décida de retourner à Bougouni auprès de son père pour apprendre le commerce notamment l’achat vente des articles divers.
Avec une expérience de 5 ans, Monsieur Drissa Sidibé maitrise son activité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires  il décida d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso afin d’acheter  une grande quantité d’articles de boutique.
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali).
Ses clients sont composés d’hommes et femmes. 
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir à ses besoins et réinvestir dans les affaires
texts.en:
Mr. Sidibe is a married man aged 29 and the father of one child. He lives with his wife and child at his father’s place in the Dougounina district of Bougouni. Having dropped out of school when in “fundamental” 6th year (Malian education system), he decided to set off in search of adventure and of a better life. Disappointed in his expectations, he decided to go back to his father’s in Bougouni and to learn commerce, mainly buying and selling various articles. Now with five years’ experience, Mr. Sidibe is mastering his business. Looking for additional financial resources, he has decided to enter Soro Yriwaso loan program in order to purchase an important quantity of goods. He gets his supplies in Bamako (capital of the republic of Mali). His customers are both men and women. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 70,000 francs CFA to provide for his needs and to invest in business.

Translated from French by viviane reignier, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various items

loans.name: Nyamirima Twimukye, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
Hardworking Mauda K. has been running a used-garment sales business since 2005 in Bumbaire, Bushenyi. This determined lady has, by all standards, tried to maintain her business that she started with little capital from the savings she made from her erstwhile banana sales business. What has made her business grow is the fact that the locals are inclined to secondhand clothing because of their low incomes.

This married mother of five, makes 45,000 shillings on a monthly basis. Her main setback is having a small amount of stock; therefore acquiring this loan will help Mauda buy more bales of clothes so that she can have a wide range of presentable garments that she hopes will attract more customers. This will enable her to get more sales revenue and be able to pay her children's school fees.

Mauda belongs to a group of members who hold each other accountable in paying back their loans; they are on their 13th loan.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of used clothes

loans.name: Loida

texts.en:
Loida I. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Loida is married and has three school-aged children. Loida owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising chickens for sale. Loida has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Loida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 5,000 PHP and was used purchase baby livestock to raise & sell.

Loida is now requesting her second loan from ASKI, for 6,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase even more livestock feed & supplies.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Chhay

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 40, has a life partner in her husband who works planting crops and they live in a rural area of Kompong Tom Province. S. currently earns her daily revenue by working as a requirement (casual) laborer. She is also hired by people to clean up their farmlands and typically earns approximately $2 each day. S. has six children who are now single and almost all of whom work in various jobs.

S. will use this first loan she has requested to purchase supplies such as seed, fertilizer and insecticide for her husband to use.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for her husband such as seed, fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur Salif Traoré est un homme marié de 37 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants chez son père à Bougouni dans le quartier Médine.
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, dès son jeune âge il commença les activités génératrices de revenus.
 Après plusieurs activités mais sans réussite, il décide d’apprendre les activités d’achat et de vente des appareils électroniques, auprès d’un ami. Avec plus de 5 ans d’expérience, Monsieur Salif Traoré maitrise son activité d’achat et la vente des appareils électroniques.
Dans le cadre du renforcement de ses activités, il décida de rejoindre le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son deuxième prêt et le précédent a été correctement remboursé.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter une quantité importante d’appareils électroniques et accessoires.                                                                                                                                                                               Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et Bamako (capitale de république du Mali).
La vente se fait au marché de Bougouni et une partie dans les  marchés hebdomadaires des  villages environnants.
Monsieur Salif Traoré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA.
Avec ces bénéfices il envisage construire une maison pour son avenir et ceux de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Mr Salif Traoré is 37 years old and married with 2 children. He lives with his wife and children at his father's house in Bougouni, in the Médine district. Having never attended school, he started income generating activities at a young age. After several unsuccessful attempts, he decided to learn from a friend about the business of buying and selling electronic devices. With more than 5 years experience, Mr Salif Traoré is mastering the business of buying and selling electronic appliances. As a means of further developing his business, he has decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's credit program. This is his second loan and the first was diligently repaid. This loan will be used to buy a significant quantity of electronic appliances and accessories. He gets his supplies at Bougouni and Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). He sells his goods at the market in Bougouni and also at the daily markets in surrounding villages. Mr Salif Traoré expects to generate a monthly profit of 75 000FCFA. With this profit he hopes to build a house for his future, and for that of his children.

Translated from French by Kate Bennett, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase electronic appliances

loans.name: Mrs. Nai Korn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has fifteen people who have selected Mrs. Nai K. as a village bank president, and is located in Trapeang Chrey village in Kandal province. They will each use a small piece of the loan for different purposes to improve their businesses. 

Mrs. Nai K. is 46 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Meng Noun, are farmers who own a one-hectare plot of the land where they can grow rice to sell to support their family. They have a problem in that their field is far away from any irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Nai K. is applying for a loan to buy a watering machine and with rest of the loan she will buy a battery. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others are attending a local public school.

loans.use: to buy a watering machine

loans.name: Remedios

texts.en:
Remedios M. is from the village of Brgy. Maddiangat, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Remedios is married and has four infant children. Remedios owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing & shoe products in the local community. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,200 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 6,000 PHP and was used purchase additional products to sell.

Remedios is now requesting her third loan from ASKI, for 9,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase new items to expand product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase new items to expand her product offerings.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand store inventory

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou B. est un homme marié de 31 ans et père de 2 enfant. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Torakabougou de Bougouni (préfecture de Bougouni,  troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Très tôt, Monsieur Seydou B. a abandonné l’école pour mener  les activités économiques notamment l’achat et la vente de bicyclettes.
Il a appris cette activité dès son jeune âge avec son cousin.
Avec une expérience de 8 ans, Monsieur Seydou Bagayogo maitrise parfaitement son activité.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali). La vente de ses bicyclettes se fait au marché de Bougouni. Sa clientèle est composée de la population locale.
Afin de satisfaire les besoins de sa clientèle, Monsieur Seydou B. décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso, afin d’acheter 15 bicyclettes.
Monsieur Seydou B. vend ses bicyclettes au comptant ou à crédit. Il est beaucoup sollicité à la rentrée des classes car chaque enfant veut avoir une bicyclette.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Seydou compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de120 000FCFA.
Avec ce bénéfice, il compte agrandir son entreprise et  assurer les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou B. is a 31-year-old married father of two. He lives with his wife and children in the Torakabougou neighborhood of the city of Bougouni (Bougouni prefecture in Sikasso, the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mr. B. left school early to go into business, primarily buying and selling bicycles. He learned the business at a young age from his cousin. With 8 years of experience, he has become an expert at his business. He buys his stock in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) and sells his bicycles in the market in Bougouni. His customer base is made up of local residents. To satisfy his customers’ needs, Mr. Seydou B. decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso in order to purchase 15 bicycles. Mr. B. sells his bicycles on a cash or credit basis. He has very high demand at the beginning of the school year, since every child wants a bicycle. With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 120,000 FCFA (West African CFA francs). With this income, he hopes to expand his business and pay his family’s expenses.

Translated from French by Rachel Braff, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bicycles for resale

loans.name: Rosevelita

texts.en:
Rosevelita S. is from the village of Brgy. Malasin, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 37 years old. Rosevelita is married and has six infant children. Rosevelita owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs, fattening them for sale. Rosevelita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 45,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) when she sells her raised animals.

In 2008, Rosevelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid her last loan from ASKI, which was for 8,000 PHP and was used purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.

Rosevelita is now requesting her fourth loan from ASKI, for 11,000 PHP, which will be used to to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to purchase additional livestock feed & supplies.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: 10.15.04 Dong Son Group

texts.en:
Thuy T. B. is a 48 year old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. Thuy is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 04-Dong Son (10.15.04).

Thuy is married and has 3 school-aged children.  To making a living, Thuy owns & operates a business venture in the food sector running a food stall.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling rice products in the local community.  Thuy has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and earns approximately 21,000,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, Thuy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thuy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase new equipment & tools to expand the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6,000,000 VND, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. The loan will be the 20th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thuy plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  T. T. Han (4) is a 63 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
2.  LeT. Hue (9) is a 26 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.
3.  D. T. Thuy (10) is a 37 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.
4.  P. T. B. Hue (34) is a 33 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.
5.  P. T. Thien (23) is a 58 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
6.  L. T. Van (18) is a 59 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.
7.  N. T. Thinh (35) is a 54 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store.
8.  L. T. Nhan (11) is a 43 year old femaL. who is requesting a 6,000,000 VND loan to support her business in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Thuy T. B. (2) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Thuy là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 9 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 04-Dong Son (10.15.04).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm từ gạo trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Thuy thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Thuy kiếm được khoảng 21000000 VND.  Vào 2004, Thuy đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Thuy đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua T.ết bị & dụng cụ mới để mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 20th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

6.  L. T. Van (18) là 59 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.
