Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Soumaila

texts.fr:
Monsieur Soumaila Samaké est homme marié de 45 ans et père de 2 enfants. Il vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni.
Monsieur Soumaila Samaké a abandonné l’école dés son jeune âge. Il  tenta pendant des années, différentes activités sans succès. Alors il décida d’apprendre les activités de collage et de soudure auprès de son oncle.
Avec une expérience de 4 ans Monsieur Soumaila maîtrise son activité.
Pour obtenir un fonds de roulement indispensable à la bonne marche de ses activités , il décide de rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 15 douzaines de baguettes, 3 pneus et  20 chambres à air.
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali.) Son atelier est situé au bord la route reliant Bougouni à Sikasso. Sa clientèle est  diverse et variée.
Il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour améliorer son entreprise pour bien attirer la clientèle.
texts.en:
Mr. Soumaila Samaké is married and the father of two children. He lives with his wife and children in the North Hérémakono borough of Bougouni. Mr. Soumaila Samaké left school at an early age. He tried his hand at different activities without success. He then decided to learn from his uncle the business of glueing and welding. After four years’ experience he has mastered this activity. To acquire the working capital necessary for the proper running of his business, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso where he is requesting a first loan. We will use the loan to buy 15 dozen welding rods, three tires and 20 inner tubes. He gets his supplies in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali). His workshop is located on the road linking Bougouni to Sikasso. His customers are diverse and varied. He is expecting to attain monthly earnings of 65,000 FCFA he will use to improve his business and attract more customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Alou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Alou Fané est un homme marié de 41 ans et père de 3 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants  chez lui même à Bougouni dans le quartier Torakabougou.(troisième région du Mali)
Après avoir passé quelques années à l’école coranique, il décida de l’abandonner pour mener des activités économiques.
Il fut d’abord ouvrier à Bamako, puis à Ouelessebougou, mais sans succès. Alors, il décida d’apprendre auprès de son oncle l’achat et la vente des pièces détachées.
Avec une expérience de plus de 10 années, il maitrise son activité dans laquelle il est très sollicité et apprécié.
Après avoir correctement remboursé ses trois prêts précédents, il est à son quatrième prêt individuel, qui sera utilisé pour acheter une importante quantité de pièces détachées. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako et effectue sa vente à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA
 Dans les années à venir il envisage agrandir son magasin.
texts.en:
Mister Alou Fané is 41 years old, married and the father of 3 children. He lives in his own home with his wife and children in Bougouni in the district of Torakabougou (third region of Mali). After spending a few years in Koranic school, he decided to give up and undertake business activities. He was first a worker in Bamako, then in Ouelessebougou, but without success. He then decided to learn from his uncle the business of buying and selling spare parts. With more than 10 years of experience, he masters his activity in which he is assailed by requests and appreciated. After repaying successfully his three previous loans, this is his fourth individual loan. It will be used to purchase a large quantity of spare parts. He buys his supplies in Bamako and sells to a variety of customers. With this loan, he plans to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA. In the upcoming years he plans to increase the size of his store.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Mrs. Sim Phol Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sim P. is a village bank president who has been selected by the nine people who make up a village bank loan located in Preaek Touch-II village in Kandal province. They all will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes which will improve their businesses in the future. 

Mrs. Sim P. is 36 years old and owns a general store at her home where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mrs. Sim P. is applying for a loan to buy more groceries to resell. She is a widow with a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: to buy groceries to resell

loans.name: Mrs. La Hen Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This loan is meant for a group of 11 people, who are based out of Preaek Touch-II village in Kandal province. The group members are requesting a loan to help improve their businesses in the future, and have selected Mrs. La H. as the village bank president, or the group leader. 

Mrs. La H. is 55 years old. She and her husband, Mr. Khorn Kai, are farmers who own a two-point five-hectare plot of land, where they grow crop for sale to support their family. They are facing trouble because they have no money to buy seeds to grow crops, and their field is also made up of infertile soil. In order to improve production, Mrs. La H. is seeking a loan to buy seeds, fertilizers, and rent a plow machine to plow her field. She has four children: one is a laborer, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one helps her in farming, and one attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers, and rent a plow machine to plow her field

loans.name: Mrs. Chorn Horn Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Thmei-II village in Kandal province, nine people make up a village bank loan group. Each of them will use part of the loan for a different purpose to improve their business. Mrs. CH. H. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. She was born in 1951. She is a farmer who owns a one-point five-hectare of land, where she grows crop for sale to support her family. Since her farming is going well she wants to expand her business. So to improve production, Mrs. CH. H. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizers, and gasoline to increase crop yield this current year. She is a widow with three children, two of whom help her in farming, while the other attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and gasoline

loans.name: Saltanat's Group

texts.en: Saltanat A., 52, is a school teacher in Bokonbaevo. Her income, however, is not enough to live a comfortable life. Since she has been widowed, she receives no additional financial help in her household. She has two sons: one in college and the other in high school. Saltanat, though, is a strong woman and has taken care of the necessities by filling up her day up with other activities like cattle breeding, which she has now been doing for four years. She started cattle breeding with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS and now makes a 3,000 KGS monthly profit. She plans to use this loan to purchase a personal computer for her younger son to use in school. Saltanat’s longer term plans are to increase the number of cattle on her farm and to contribute money to her elder son’s wedding. Saltanat has three partners: Baktygul A., 42, is the treasurer of the group. She is also in the business of purchasing cattle and reselling them after fattening. She has been doing this for three years, ever since she divorced and her friends suggested she start this business. She began with a 10,000 KGS investment and today makes a 4,000 KGS monthly profit. With the loan, Baktygul wants to purchase four cows to increase her turnover. Farhat A. is an impressive 22-year old. He successfully graduated from second year at the university and, in order to do this, had to take out a loan. To pay off his loan he began selling cattle, fish, and agricultural products. He started this business one year ago with 5,000 KGS and now makes a 4,000 KGS profit. He would like another loan to buy more cattle and increase the amount of his herd. His future plans are to graduate, to marry, and to find a good job. Sabira B., 69, wants to have enough money to support her daughter and grandchildren. Her daughter is 25 and works in a nursery, earning 5,000 KGS per month. Sabira looks after her grandchildren and breeds cattle. She is a widow and, following her neighbors’ advice, began to breed cattle with an initial investment of 10,000 KGS. Now she makes 1,500 KGS per month. She would like to use the loan to purchase hay for her cattle. --- Where Did This Loan Come From? --- This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase a personal computer for her son to use in school

loans.name: Mrs. Savy Pov  Village Bank Group

texts.en: In Thmei-II village in Kandal province, eight people make up a village bank loan group. The group members have selected Mrs. Savy P. as the village bank president. Each of them will use a piece of the loan for a different purpose to improve their business in the future. Mrs. Savy P. is 39 years old and is a farmer. She owns a two-point four-hectare plot of land, where she grows crop for sale to support her family. It's time to plow her field but she is facing difficulty in having enough money to complete the task. So to improve production, Mrs. Savy P. is requesting a loan to rent a plow machine to plow her field. Her husband, Mr. Chhan Doeurn Oeurn, is a fisherman. She is a mother of two children, both of whom are enrolled in the local public school.

loans.use: To rent a plow machine to plow her field

loans.name: Stephanie

texts.en:
Stephanie T., 40, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Heradeo T., 48, a driver, they are blessed with two children. Managing her own variety store for ten years now, Stephanie makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that her family can have a better life.

Stephanie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now, regularly attending their weekly fellowship meetings and consistently paying her weekly dues. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative, using the money she borrows to expand and improve her businesses.

To ensure the continued success of her businesses, she is now requesting a PHP 25,000 loan to be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses. Stephanie will buy replenishment stock for her variety store. She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for their children’s education.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional products to be incorporated into her current product inventory

loans.name: Yea

texts.en: Mrs. V., 53, is skilled at combining many types of root trees. She also buys root trees from the forest people and turns them into natural medicine, selling her products to patients who are neighbors living in the village. She is married to a vehicle repairman. V. is requesting her loan to order more raw materials to make medicine, with the remainder being used to meet some of the requirements of her husband’s business.

loans.use: To order more raw materials.

loans.name: Mrs. Saroeun Bo Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of twelve people who are villagers in Krapeu Ha village in Kandal province. Mrs. Saroeun B. is the village bank president, selected by the other members. Each member will use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose to improve their business. Mrs. Saroeun B. is 51 years old and is a rice and congee (rice porridge) seller in her local village. She is a widow with four children: one is a seamstress in a garment factory, one is a policeman, one helps her in selling rice and congee, and one attends the local public school. She is facing difficulty because her house is broken. So to improve this condition, Mrs. Saroeun B. is asking for a loan to fix her house.

loans.use: To fix her own house

loans.name: Mrs. Mom Kin Village Bank Group

texts.en: Fourteen people make up the village bank loan group, and they live in Krapeu Ha village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mom K. has been selected as the group leader by the other members. Each member will use a small piece of the loan for a different purpose to improve their business. Mrs. Mom K. was born in 1968. She is a Khmer cake maker at her home. Her husband, Mr. Vuthy Touch, is employed in a telecom business. Although this couple works hard, they earn less income. So to improve her family's lifestyle, Mrs. Mom K. is asking for a loan to start a new business to buy more groceries for resale. She is a mother of four children: one is a teacher, two are employed in a telecom business, and one attends the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resale to start a new business

loans.name: Mrs. Chanthou Oll Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of eight people, led by Mrs. Chanthou O.. All residents of Preaek Thei village in Kandal Province, they will each use their portion of the loan to improve their businesses.

Mrs. Chanthou O., a 28-year-old widow, owns a general store that enables her to support her two children, one of whom is enrolled in local public schoO., while the youngest one is two years old. Since her business is going well she wants to expand and so is requesting the loan to buy more groceries to sell.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to resale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose J. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and bread from home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Thirty-eight years old and married to a farmer, she has three children, all attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, Rose hopes to be able to expand her charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more stacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Gulzat's Group

texts.en:
Gulzat S. is 35; she is the leader of the group. Her husband works as a security guard and Gulzat is a secretary in the district veterinary station. They also breed cattle and cultivate fruit and vegetables to make some money. Every year Gulzat and her husband sow wheat and barley, so they don’t need to purchase any food for their cattle. They started farming five years ago with an initial investment of 2,000 soms. Now Gulzat wants to get a loan to pay for tractor services and purchase 500 kilograms of wheat seed. In the future, she wants to build a new house.

Shairbubu Z. is 50 and has two sons and a daughter. Her daughter studies at school. Her older son has gone to work in Russia to make some money. Her younger son studies at university in Bishkek and works on construction to be able to pay for his study. Shairbubu’s husband is retired and he started to breed cattle two years ago with an initial investment of 15,000 soms. Now, by selling some cattle after fattening he makes 4,500 soms per month. Shairbubu applied for the loan because she wants to contribute money for her younger son’s education.

Meerim A. is 31 and a widow. She has a six-year-old daughter and to support her, Meerim does different activities. She takes orders and sews national clothing and provides dressmaking supplies. She also breeds and fattens cattle for sale. With money received from the loan she wants to purchase 10 sheep to increase the number of livestock. In the future, Meerim wants to buy a vehicle.

Turarkul S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 48, a widow and has raised three sons and a daughter. Her daughter works in a sewing workshop, the youngest son is at school, and her other sons work in Russia at the cannery.  Five years ago with an initial investment of 20,000 soms, Turarkul started to sell second-hand clothes and now she earns 5,000 soms per month. She wants to get a loan to repair the house and buy building material to construct a kitchen. In the future she wants to expand her business and contribute some money for her daughter’s wedding.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To purchase wheat seed

loans.name: Nazri

texts.ru: Чаборова Назри проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 47 лет. Замужем, имеет 2 детей. Муж, не работает. Сама Назри имеет среднее образование. Более 5 лет занимается торговлей. У нее магазинчик, где она продает продукты питания. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en:
Nazri C. lives in the Rudaki district. She is 47 years old, married and has 2 children. Her husband does not work. Nazri has a secondary education. She has been involved in retail sales for over 5 years. She has a store, where she sells food products. Nazri is requesting this loan in order to expand the product assortment.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding product assortment

loans.name: Mrs. Oeun Sem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Prek They village in Kandal province a group of eight people have selected Mrs. Oeun S. as a village bank president. They all will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes to improve the condition their businesses. 

Mrs. Oeun Sun is 59 years old. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the other is attending a local public school.  She and her husband, Mr. Lang S., are farmers own a small piece of the land to grow crops to sell to support their family. 

Now they have some problems because their field has infertile soil and it is far away from irrigation. So to improve production, Mrs. Oeun S. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Leonesa

texts.en:
Leonesa T., 34, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Sally T., 35, a sewer, they are blessed with four children. She helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life. She has been managing her own tailoring business for 14 years now.

Leonesa has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she has been able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She uses the money she borrows to expand and improve her business which helps her to consistently pay her dues.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a 10,000 PHP loan. This will be used to provide added capital for her expanding business so she can buy her own additional sewing machine.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for their children’s education.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy her own sewing machine

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa M. is currently in the business of selling clothes and bed sheets at the market and is requesting a loan so she can stock pairs of shoes to sell. Hawa is 40 years old and is married with a husband who is a policeman. She has five children who all go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to establish a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy pairs of shoes to sell

loans.name: Tuong

texts.en: Mrs. S., 32, is a humble villager living in Kompong Tom Province. She earns a daily income by working as a casual laborer. S.'s husband also earns an income by providing music with a traditional instrument for wedding parties. This couple currently live with three children who are young and attend school. S. and her husband always plant a rice crop which is an annual business that they done with great success. The coming rainfall season is good for growing crops but S. does not have money to buy supplies to use on her field. Thus, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide and crop seeds to begin planting.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide and crop seeds for planting

loans.name: Mrs. Moeurn Meth Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of nine people who live in Preaek Thei village Kandal province. Mrs. Moeurn M. is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will each use a small piece of the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns small piece of the land to grow crops to sell to support her family. 

Now she has some problems because her field has infertile soil and is far away from an irrigation system. So to improve production, Mrs. Moeurn M. is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. She is a widow with three children, three of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the other is attending a local public school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Alagush's Group

texts.en:
Alagush S., 59, helps her husband in the cattle-breeding business. They have been doing this for 10 years, beginning with 6,000 KGS. Today, they make a monthly profit of 10,000 KGS. Saving up, little by little, they have been able to buy a vehicle. Alagush also works as a bookkeeper. She has four daughters who are all married. She is asking for a loan in order to repair the family’s animal shed, where they sometimes keep their cattle.

Alagush has four partners, all of whom work in a lab at a veterinary clinic (among other things):

Kuliypa A., 55, lives by herself and has a cattle-breeding business. All her children are married. Her younger son helps her with her business which she started five years ago with 2,000 KGS and now makes 3,000 KGS per month. Her first achievement was that she was able to contribute money for her son's wedding. Now she is asking for a loan to buy three calves. She is planning that the calves will graze in the mountains until August.

Gulnara A., 43, works in a veterinary clinic. She is a widow and has four daughters ranging from ages 12 to 19. She plans to use the loan to pay for medical expenses for one of her daughters .

Damira Z. wants to use the loan to buy furniture for her home. She is 55 and married, Her husband used to work on a collective farm but when the collectives broke down, he started breeding cattle. They started this seven years ago with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS. Now they make 4,000 KGS per month and with this profit, they were able to build a house. Damira has one son who is 20 years old and currently at college.

Ainagul A., 58, has a daughter who is a student. Ainagul's husband is retired, so Ainagul and her husband breed cattle to make money. They have been doing this for six years, starting with an initial investment of 3,000 KGS. Now they earn 3,000 KGS per month. With the money received from the loan, Ainagul would like to pay for national mandatory military training. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young, ambitious and socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the Mol Bulak Finance staff.

loans.use: To repair the family's animal shed

loans.name: Oyungerel

texts.en:
Oyungerel is a widow who is 46 years old and lives with two daughters and one son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger (a Mongolian nomadic tent). One of her younger daughters attends the university. Her son, Purevdorj, has just returned from the army so that he might be able to get a job in the city.

Oyungerel operates a fruit and vegetable retail business. She purchases fruit and vegetables from the Narantuul and Bars markets, the two largest markets in Ulaanbaatar, and sells them to people for a profit. Her business is doing very well, thanks partly to help from her daughter. Oyungerel has good communication skills and her business is very important to her. She has many plans for the future, and says, “My aim is to create my own shop by working hard and stabilizing my current business.” She is applying for a loan of 450,000 MNT to buy fruit and vegetables at wholesale prices to resell to her many customers.

loans.use: To buy fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Nunu

texts.en:
Nunu A. is currently in the business of selling books in her bookshop and is requesting a loan to buy boxes of pens, pencils and pencil sharpeners. Nunu is 39 years old and is married with a husband who is a clinical officer. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her bookshop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy boxes of pens, pencils and pencil sharpeners to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Phy Chum Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Ten people have selected Mrs. Phy C. as a village bank president in Preaek Thei village of Kandal province. All of them will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Phy C. is 50 years old and a widow with four children, three of whom are seamstresses in garment factory, while the other is attending a local public school. She is a rice seller at her local market where she can earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it. So to improve this business, Mrs. Phy C. is asking for a loan to buy more rice to resell.

loans.use: to buy rice for resale

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. is currently in the business of selling various medications at her pharmacy and is requesting a loan to stock more medications to sell.  Susan is 42 years old and is married with a husband who is a director general. She has four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend her pharmacy floor.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more medications to sell

loans.name: Baigalmaa

texts.en:
Baigalmaa V. is 49 years old and lives with her husband and 21-year-old daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in an apartment which the family was able to buy owing to their business profits. Her husband currently works for a company as a driver.

Baigalmaa operates a hair salon in the rented basement of an apartment in Ulaanbaatar where she employs three hairdressers and a massager. She started the hair salon in 2006 and her business has progressed in a short time with many clients. She has been working as a hairdresser for more than 16 years. She works very hard and is a clever woman. For the future, Baigalmaa hopes to change her workplace. She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase vacuum windows and some kitchen furniture for her apartment.

loans.use: To purchase vacuum windows and furniture

loans.name: 12.1.2 Nam Ngan Group

texts.en:
Soan L. T. (5) is a 48-year-old femaL. living in the town of Thanh Hoa. She is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 12.1.2 Nam Ngan.

Soan is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Soan operates a family member's service-based business. WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing cargo transport services to local community members. Soan has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2009, Soan joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1.626.900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women which was used to repair a transport vehicL. used in the business. She is now requesting a new loan of 6.000.000 VND which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide cargo transport services. This will be the second loan Soan has taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About the other borrowers in the group:

1.  L. T. Quyen (6) is a 23-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the services sector operating a tailoring business.

2.  N. T. Hoa (7) is a 35-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

3.  T. T. Van (8) is a 29-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

4.  L. T. Yen (9) is a 51-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6.000.000 VND loan to support her business in the food sector running a food stall.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Soan L. T. (5) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Thanh Hoa.  Soan là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 12.1.2 Nam Ngan (02.12.1.2).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ cung cấp các dịch vụ vận chuyển hàng hóa cho người dân trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Soan thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 5 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Soan kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2009, Soan đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Soan đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1.626.900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng sửa chữa phương tiện vận chuyển được dùng trong công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 6.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Quyen (6) là 23 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực dịch vụ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh may mặc.


2.  N. T. Hoa (7) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


3.  T. T. Van (8) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


4.  L. T. Yen (9) là 51 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là buôn bán quầy thực phẩm.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide cargo transport services

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more foodstuffs to sell at the restaurant. Mary is 39 years old and is married to a businessman. She has two children, both of whom go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house to rent.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell in a restaurant.

loans.name: Onon

texts.en: Onon is 37 years old and lives with his wife and 4 children in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His three daughters attend a secondary school and his wife stays at home with his one year-old son Temuujin. Onon operates a trucking business with his Kia Fronter truck, which has a capacity of two tons. He is a very hard-working person and his business is very important to him. Onon says, “As a father, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children until they grow up. Also, I would like to expand my business and to purchase my own apartment for my family in the future.” He is requesting a loan to purchase four tires and other spare parts for his truck.

loans.use: To purchase four tires and other spare parts for his truck.

loans.name: Mr. Saveoun Kae Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan has nine people who live in Roluos village in Kandal province. Mr. Saveoun K. has been selected by the other members to be the  village bank president. Each member will use a small piece of the loan to buy something that will better their family's standard of living.

Mr. Saveoun K. was born in 1950. He is a teacher in a local school.  He is also a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Sambour Phem, is rice a middleman who can earn some money to support the family. Now his wife’s business is going well so she wants to expand it. Mr. Saveoun K. is therefore asking for a loan to buy more rice to resell. He is a father of a child who is attending a local public school.

loans.use: to buy more rice for resale

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Chona M., 49, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Vergel M., 39, a company driver, they are blessed with seven children. She makes sure that she helps her husband so that their family can have a better life. Chona has been managing her own aluminum, glass, wood and iron works, while selling basic commodities at her variety store for quite some time now.

Chona has been a regular member of  Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative. She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her variety store.

To ensure the success of her business, she would like to apply for a PHP 9,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to help expand her business by buying more stock to be incorporated in to her current product inventory, as well as spare parts for her iron works.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy inventory and spare parts for iron, aluminum, glass and wood works.

loans.name: Muhasima

texts.en:
Muhasima K is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell.  Muhasima is 31 years old and is married to a teacher. She and her husband have two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand the bar by stocking various hot drinks and wines etc.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more beer to sell.

loans.name: Habal

texts.en: T. Habal is 38 years old and lives with his wife and four children in Bayan-Ulgiy province in western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a small house. His oldest three children currently attend a local secondary school and his youngest is in kindergarden. Habal's wife, Juldiz, is also self-employed and operates a clothing business. Habal operates a raw material trading business in his town. His major products consist of sheep and goat skins. Habal started his business in 1999 by purchasing and selling the animal skins in his local area. However, to take advantage of higher demand and profit potential, he now transports and sells the skins in Ulaanbaatar, the largest city and capital of Mongolia. He continues to make progress with his business and uses his earnings to improve his family's quality of life. With the continued success of both of their businesses, Habal and his wife hope to use their earnings to add on to their home. Habal is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase raw materials for his animal skins business and coal for his own use.

loans.use: To purchase inventory and coal.

loans.name: Mrs. Peng Lem Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Srae Ambil 3 village in Kandal province a village bank loan group of nine people has selected Mrs. Peng L. as the village bank president. All the members will use a small piece of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Peng L. was born in 1961. She and her husband, Mr. Tha Khlout, catch and sell fish to support their family. But now they have some problems because their fishing supplies are too old to use. So to address this, Mrs. Peng L. is applying for a loan to buy fishing supplies and a battery. She is a mother of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: to buy fishing supplies

loans.name: Hourt

texts.en:
Mrs. Hourt S. is one of many Cambodian people who earn a living by planting crops. She is 41 years old and is the mother of five children, all of whom are single and work, and they live together in the farming home. Hourt S. has a life partner in her husband who works on the farm with her.

The coming rainfall season allows for farming but Hourt S. does not have money to buy any supplies to use on her field. Thus, she is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, insecticide, and crop seeds to plant.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, insecticide, and crop seeds to plant

loans.name: Mrs. Son Sam Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Son S., a 57-year-old mother of three children who are seamstresses in a garment factory, is a village bank president selected by ten people living in Chrolong village in Kandal Province. All the group members will use their portion of the loan for various ways.

Mrs. Son S., along with her husband, Mr. Sen San, cultivates rice for sale on their half-hectare of land in order to support their family. She is now applying for a loan for her farm and to fix her house.

loans.use: For her farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her shop

loans.name: Sreimoa

texts.en: Mrs. Sreimoa Y., a resident of Preaek Hang village in Kandal Province, was born 1979 and owns a small piece of the land upon which she grows crops to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vany Sieng, is a fisherman.  In order to improve his catch, she is seeking a loan to buy fishing equipment for his business. Sreimoa is a mother of six children, four of whom are attending in local public school, while the youngest two are yet too young to attend.

loans.use: To buy fishing equipment

loans.name: Grisha

texts.en:
Grisha M. was born in 1957 in Sarigyugh village, Ijevan area. He is married and has two children: his daughter lives separately from their parents, and his son's family lives with Grisha and his wife.

Grisha and his son work for hire as builders (particularly in the summer and autumn months) and at the same time Grisha’s family has been engaged in farming. On their farm they have cows, calves and pigs. With the profit from animal husbandry they support their family.

Grisha asks for a 350,000 AMD loan to buy three or four pigs for his farm, which will help him to improve his family's well-being in the future.

loans.use: To buy three or four pigs for his farm

loans.name: Thang

texts.en:
In the photo is Mrs. Thang S., a young woman and mother. She built a grocery store where she sells her inventory to nearby people for a profit. She sells items such as cooking ingredients, cane-goods, and sweets (candies) for kids. In addition to her grocery business, she raises a few pigs that she will sell to the slaughterer when they come to maturity. By doing her jobs, she is able to make $5 a day to support the daily expenses of her family.

Thang S. is married with two babies who are dependent on her. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver.

Thang S. requests a loan to book the plantation where the cashews grow. She estimates that she will harvest and sell the cashews to buyers for additional revenue.

loans.use: To book the plantation where the cashews grow

loans.name: Samvel

texts.en:
Samvel M. was born in 1957. He lives in Hovk village, Ijevan area, with his wife and a son.

For a long time Samvel has worked as a livestock expert in different villages. Now he has his own farm where he keeps cattle. His wife and son help him in this hard work and thereby support their family.

At the moment, Samvel has some newborn (2-3 months) calves and he needs a 300,000 AMD loan to buy fodder for them.

loans.use: To buy fodder for his calves

loans.name: Budumbuli East Development Group, Jinja

texts.en:
38-year-old K. Glades is a sturdy, evergreen and down-to-earth married woman. For a decade now she has been plying a roaring trade in her restaurant business in Bugembe, Jinja. The fact that she has been doing great business all this while goes without saying. Of paramount importance to her in establishing a firm niche in the minds of her customers and on the market has been the embracing of good customer care skills. This in many respects worked in her favor.

Glades began with a pancake-selling business before she nurtured the whole idea of setting up this restaurant business. To manifest that she and her family can live within the means provided by this business, all her five children are attending good schools and she has bought a commercial taxi.

In the course of time, Glades has reached a satisfactory profit-maximizing point in her business. In a week, she makes profits to the tune of 120,000 shillings and she is anticipating even better prospects with the acquisition of this loan. She also ekes out supplementary profits from her taxi business. The purchase of substantial amounts of foodstuffs for her restaurant is what is in the offing for her.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs for her restaurant business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase cement and steel reinforcements to sell

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina Q. is divorced and has one child. Faustina sells gari (cassava flakes) and also processes coconut oil at Takoradi for sale. She has no educational backgound. She uses her income to look after her child.

Faustina will use the loan to purchase coconuts to use for the production of coconut oil. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to add to her initial capital.

loans.use: To purchase coconuts for the production of coconut oil

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sewing machines and other work materials

loans.name: Dilrabokhon

texts.en: H. Dilrabokhon is 38 years old and is married with three children. She sells sweets (candies), preserved food, juices, soft drinks and also detergents in her grocery store. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Dilrabokhon is respectful and patient with all of her customers which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. Dilrabokhon is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 4,000 Somoni to increase the inventory she has for sale. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help her reach all of her aspirations. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to increase the range of her goods

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase rice, oil, charcoal, and other products

loans.name: Davlatgul

texts.ru: Сатторова Давлатгул проживает в районе Рудаки. Возраст, 69 лет. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Она берет заказы на дому. Ей в продвижении ее деятельности помогает дочка. Она продает готовые платья на рынке. Этим видом деятельности Давлатгул занимается уже 40 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения ниток и бисера, т.е. необходимых вещей для шитья.
texts.en:
Davlatgul S. lives in the Rudaki district. She is 69 years old, a widow and has 2 children. She has a secondary education and is involved in sewing national dresses. She accepts orders at home. Her daughter helps her with advancing her business. She sells finished dresses at a market. Davlatgul has been involved in this business for 40 years. She is requesting this loan in order to buy threads and beads, i.e. necessary items for sewing.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of threads and beads

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Born in 1956, Rose N.  is married to Chi Joseph and they have brought forth five children. As a woman who does not like to depend on her husband for all the family needs and finding it so difficult to accomplish this task, Rose N.  joined GHAPE in 1998. Also, she has been having a lot of marital problems with her family.This has made her sad all the time but she is appreciative of the fact that she is alive. Her desire is to give her children love and education. She states that she feels better each time she provides something small to her children. Her inability to get investment capital which could constantly generate income for her to meet her children’s needs is what motivated her to obtain a loan from GHAPE.

Given a loan, she plans to buy a two-wheeled motorcycle. She knows this business will succeed because she is located at a good business site and she has a good rider for the motorcycle. She  plans to use the profits generated to sponsor her children in school and to cater for the basic needs of her family.  

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon.  GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.  Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values.  Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.  GHAPE instills a sense of family and community in its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Purchase of a two-wheeled motorcycle

loans.name: Sarvar

texts.en:
K. Sarvar is dedicated to his agricultural business. Having little knowledge in the beginning, he had to learn a lot about farming. Now, he has acquired a fair experience in agriculture. Currently, Sarvar is very happy, for his two children are the motivation for his desire to grow his business. He approached IMON International to obtain a loan to buy seeds and fertilizer to sow for a good harvest so that he can take care of his children and his home.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: I Trust God Group

texts.en:
Weedor S., who is holding the sign, is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'I Trust God'. She is 28 years old, single and has two children who are 8 and 2 years old. She is a sophomore student. Both of her children are attending school.

For 10 years, she has been selling charcoal and soap at Redlight Market, Paynesville outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 30,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 115,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of charcoal and more cartons of soap. She describes herself as a reliable and hard-working person.

Her dream is to grow her business and educate her children so that they can have a better future.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Ruth is inset at lower right because she was absent during the interview.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal and more cartons of soap

loans.name: Farida

texts.en:
K. Farida is a dynamic and ambitious 41-year-old woman. She is married and has one child. For 15 years already she has had a small business processing apricots. Thanks to the quality of her products and the experience she has gained in this sphere of business, she has earned a solid reputation among her customers and the demand for her goods has grown, allowing Farida to contribute significantly to the household. 

Now Farida requests a loan amounting to 5000 Somoni. She is going to spend the loan purchasing apricots with the purpose of processing them and making dried apricots. Farida hopes that she will be able to continue providing her children with schooling so they will be able to get an adequate education. She expresses her gratitude to everyone supporting her.

loans.use: Purchasing apricots to process for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase materials to make shoes

loans.name: Muharram

texts.en:
K. Muharram is 44 years old. She is married with 4 children. She is a well-known seamstress in her community, seeing that she has been working there for many years. Fifteen years ago, Muharram decided to take advantage of her reputation and bought a tailoring machine and since then, she has been providing the service of a tailor. The entrepreneur says that she has now a well-established clientele, the majority of whom are young girls who often order national dresses. 

In this way, Muharram constantly adds new clients and has seen her business grow. Now she is requesting a loan of US$ 800 to purchase new modern fabrics for sewing national dresses. You can help improve the quality of life of her family. Muharram and her family are grateful for your generosity and support.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, meat, and oil

loans.name: Tavsirakhon

texts.en:
Tavsirakhon has a small business selling children’s clothing. She is a widow and has been in business for 10 years. Tavsirakhon is an energetic, enthusiastic entrepreneur who operates her business simply but wisely. An example of this are the times when she has needed to purchase new clothing inventory. Rather than close her business and travel herself to buy inventory, she has paid other clothing vendors to buy for her so that she can stay and keep her business open. 

Tavsirakhon has requested a loan to help renew her clothing inventory. The change of seasons means a busy time of year for clothing vendors. This loan will help her purchase a good supply of inventory so she can maximize her profits and continue working to develop her business.

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for children for the summer season

loans.name: Sirojitdin

texts.en:
N. Sirojitdin has always been a hard-working man, who has made sure, from his young age, that his family never goes without their daily bread. He is married with two children. 

Sirojitdin has a grocery store where he sells different kinds of foodstuffs. With a starting capital of 200 USD, thanks to his perseverance and dedication, Sirojitdin began this enterprise 5 years ago. He has expanded his business and today his family is also engaged in this business. 

Today Sirojitdin needs to buy additional foodstuffs to increase the range of his goods. With this purpose he is requesting a loan of 1000 USD. Sirojitdin is ready to work even harder, make sacrifices and push every once in a while to achieve his goal and become a successful entrepreneur. We believe his perseverance and clear vision will become key success factors in his small business.

loans.name: Domulokhon

texts.en:
O. Domulokhon is 40 years old. He is married and has 3 children. Hia wife is a housekeeper and the business of Domulokhon is the main source of income of his large family. Domulokhon has been providing transportation  services for the last two years. Each day on his lorry he transports construction materials for his clients.

Domulokhon dreams that all of his children will be well-educated; for that he is working hard. As a result the business generates significant income, allowing him supporting his large family. In order to provide better service for his clients and therefore earn more, Domulokhon needs to make major repairs to his lorry. He believes that this will make his business more profitable. For this purpose he requests $1,000 USD. The well-being of this family is in your hands.

loans.use: Purchasing of spare parts for the lorry.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for delivering his work

loans.name: Kurbonboy

texts.en: Kurbonboy is married with three children. He lives in Isfara and runs a technical store selling spare parts and lubricants. His business is very prospective and flourishing. Kurbonboy has an individual approach to each of his customers which has helped him win many loyal clients. He has been in this trade for fifteen years. Today, Kurbonboy needs a loan of 1,000 USD to increase his stock. He is happy to have access to lending services, as additional financial assistance gives him options in his dealings with different suppliers of specific merchandise. loans.use: To purchase more spare parts for cars to increase his range of goods

loans.name: Concern Sisters Group

texts.en:
Kolu B., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Concern Sisters Group. She is 29 years old, is married, and has two children who are 5 and 9 years old. She was only able to attend school through grade 12 and currently attends a vocational school. Her children are attending school. She also cares for a sibling.

For ten years, Kolu has been selling used clothes at Red Light Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She started her business with 8,000 Liberian Dollars (LRD) and now has 15,000 LRD as working capital.

Kolu plans to use her 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more bags of used clothes and ladies handbags to sell. She describes herself as a determined person.

Kolu’s goals are to open a used-clothes store and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes and ladies handbags to sell

loans.name: Jamoliddin

texts.en: S. Jamoliddin was born in 1979 and is married with three children. As an aspiring and hard-working man he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. Thus, when he joined IMON International four years ago, he was able to make much progress with his previous loan, which he invested mostly in crop farming. Then, Jamoliddin saw a new business opportunity: rearing calves, which is very profitable because of the constant demand for meat at the market. Given this loan, he will purchase calves and feed for them to expand his business. Jamoliddin plans to use the profits from his business to educate his children, improve the structure of his home, and improve the standard of living of his family. loans.use: To purchase calves in order to expand his business

loans.name: Tukhta

texts.en: T. Tukhta is 48 years old. She is married and uses all the money she makes to care for her three children and provide for their education. Tukhta has an experience of seven years preparing and selling dried apricots. She always makes very productive use of her capital, adding inventory to her supply in a way that allows her to meet her customers' needs. Tukhta is also very polite and considerate, and her clients are always very happy with the service they receive from her. Because her business is doing so well, Tukhta is increasing her net worth month by month. Today, she requests 1,000 USD to purchase apricots with the purpose of processing and making dried apricots to increase the range of her selling goods. Tukhta expresses her gratitude for everyone supporting her and promises to repay her loan in a timely manner. loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of rice, beans, flour, oil, and sugar

loans.name: Mpapai Group

texts.en:
Meet Abdul K. and the Mpapai Group!  Abdul is 41 years old and married.  He has five children between the ages of 3 and 16 years old.  His oldest four children go to school.  Abdul also supports his 20-year-old sister-in-law, who lives with the family.  Abdul started selling used clothing about ten years ago, and with the help of past loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, he now focuses on selling second-hand shoes.  Abdul has repaid all of his loans, and his business is going well.  He earns a profit of about US$ 150 per month.  

With this loan, Abdul plans to buy about 50 pairs of second-hand shoes for his shop.  He will select men's and women's shoes, sandals and boots.  With the profits, Abdul will continue to support his family and pay for food and school fees.  He hopes to reinvest additional savings into his business, and eventually open up a second location in the busy Kariako market of Dar Es Salaam. 

Abdul is the chairman of the Mpapai group.  The group's 17 members run a variety of businesses including salons, shops, tailoring, and charcoal sales.  The group's members will hold each other accountable for repaying this loan.  

In the photo, Abdul is standing 3rd from the right, wearing a white shirt.  All of the group members are pictured, however, Rehema A. is hidden at the back.  Zambda S. is covered in the front.  She wanted to be in the photo, but didn't want to show her face.

loans.use: increasing stock of shoes for sale

loans.name: God Is Able #2 Group

texts.en:
Saybah Z. who is holding the sign is the leader of a group of five borrowers called 'God Is Able #2'. She is 45 years old, married and has two children who are 20 and 22 years old. She was only able to attend school through 12th grade due to poverty. Both of her children are attending school.

For 10 years, she has been selling used clothes at Redlight Market, Paynesville, outside of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of used clothes. She describes herself as a caring mother.

Her dream is to grow her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of used clothes

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret B. sells charcoal in sacks and in smaller quantities for those who cannot afford buying in bags at Takoradi.  Margaret has received senior high education.  She is married and has three children. Her husband is a timber farmer. The loan she is hoping to receive will be used to buy more bags of charcoal for sale. She wishes to use the new profits from her business to complete her building.

loans.use: buy more bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Mt Rongai Group

texts.en:
Meet M. R. M. and the Mt. Rongai Group!  M. is 55 years old, married, and has a 20-year-old daughter who goes to school.  AdditionA., he supports the 7-year-old son of his brother-in-law, and that child also goes to school.  

For the past 3 years, M. has run a business selling dishware.  He works from around 8 am until 6 pm each day, and earns about US$ 150 per month.  M. used his two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase his inventory, and he has repaid both loans successfully.  With this loan, M. plans to purchase a new stove, cups, plates, a basin and some washing buckets.  EventuA. he hopes to expand his business from retail sales to include a wholesale component.  M. is saving his profits and hopes to finish a new home for his family, which is already partiA. constructed.  

M. is the chairman of the Mt. Rongai Group.  The group's members run a variety of businesses, including sales of clothes, fruit, charcoal, soap and fish.  The group's 16 members will hold each other accountable for repaying this loan.  

In the photo, M. is wearing an orange and white stripped shirt, 1st on the left, second row.

loans.use: Buying dishware inventory

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 47-year-old married man with three children age 18, 14 and 7.

For thirteen years Joseph has been operating Karish Metal workshop where he makes windows, doors and gates. He gets orders from the neighboring schools and the area residents. He also runs a mini-hardware shop. He was previously selling household items to earn a living.

As a businessman, Joseph decided to join a group called Rafiki Shg so that he could easily access loans from Faulu Kenya. With the group, he is able to save his money on a weekly basis. He has been an active member of the group and has previously serviced three loans from Faulu Kenya.

Joseph has requested a loan of Kes 70,000 to purchase a grinder and a welding machine. He hopes to educate his children to university level. He sees himself opening another business in ten years.

loans.use: To purchase a grinder and a welding machine

loans.name: Simion

texts.en:
Simion is an old man of 70. Together with his wife, he rears and sells cattle in Machakos and has been running this business for ten years.

Simion joined Wikwatyo Museo Group so as to access loans from Faulu Kenya. He previously took out a loan of Kes 120,000 to boost his business and he successfully repaid. He has now requested for a loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more bulls.

Simion hopes to purchase a pick-up in the future so that he can transport his bulls easily. He also plans to use the pick-up for a transport business to earn more income. He describes himself as an ambitious man.

loans.use: To buy more bulls

loans.name: Kashaka Women In Development Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Fred, a 38-year-old happy-go-lucky married man with seven children, is an evergreen optimist who carries conviction that the decisions one takes in the early stages of a business are the springboard to its success. It is a gospel he has preached – and he gladly practiced it at the start of his produce-selling business thirty years ago. He credits his business longevity to his straightforwardness and unwavering decisions.

In Kashaka where he operates from, Fred has, over the years, established for himself a ready market for his produce. In a week, his profit estimates are in the area of 30,000 shillings. He wants to use this loan to purchase more produce that he can later resell to his clients.

loans.use: To purchase more produce like bananas and cassava to sell

loans.name: Fru

texts.en:
Born in 1945, Fru A. is married to Nangah Frida and they have brought forth eight children. As a man who does not like to look too much on the wife for all the family needs, and finding it so difficult to accomplished this task as man who should be the breadwinner of the family, he joined GHAPE in 1998.

Fru has been having a lot of marital problems with his family. This has made him sad all the time but he is appreciative of the fact that he is alive. His desire is to give his children love and education. He states that he feels better each time he provides something small for his children.

Fru’s inability to get investment capital, which could constantly generate income for him to meet his children’s needs, is what motivated him to obtain a loan from GHAPE. Given the loan, he plans to sell motor spare parts. He knows this business will succeed because he is located at a good business site and he has a good sales boy who has sold for him for several years.

Fru plans to use the profits generated to sponsor his children in school and to cater for the basic needs of his family.

 The first installment will be paid on the fourth month from date of disbursement.


About GHAPE
The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO (non-governmental organization) based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach.

Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profit and loss, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement.

GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: To purchase motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Mohammad Tarek

texts.en:
Mohammad Tarek is a 21-year-old single man living in Lebanon. He has experience in selling and maintaining tires since 2005. He sells and repairs mainly truck tires and rims and his clients are mainly truck companies.

Today, for the first time, Mohammad Tarek has requested a loan to purchase a machine for tire maintenance. This machine will allow him to improve his work. He hopes that he will continue to improve and expand his work.

loans.use: To purchase a machine for tire maintenance

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is a 35-year-old man who lives with his wife and three children. He values his family and works hard to meet their needs. His wife is a business-lady and she helps her husband with the household expenses.

Julius is a hardworking man who has eleven years of experience in his Pamoja Retail shop. He sells sugar, maize flour, rice and soap and also sells vegetables to supplement his income.

As a businessman, Julius has learned how to manage his money by saving in a group in Faulu Kenya called Acis Buruburu Group. Since he joined the group, his business has really grown. This is because he was previously selling his goods in a stall and he moved to a permanent shop.

Julius has requested a loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more sugar, maize flour, rice and soap. He hopes to expand his business into wholesale in the future.

loans.use: To buy more sugar, maize flour, rice and soap for his store

loans.name: Saada

texts.en:
Saada is a 31 year old Lebanese entrepreneur. She is the mother of four children. In 2004, she decided to open a grocery store in her town. Saada also sells antiques items like vases, sculptures, watches and other decorative items. She also offers food products, breads, canned food, beverages, candies and other products to her clients.  Saada decided to open her shop because she wanted to have  independent work and  to supplement her family's income. Her clients are her friends and family members. She says that she has competitive prices and her customers feel comfortable buying from her. 
For the first time, Saada is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise for her store in the hope that it will increase her sales, and therefore, her income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma K. is 45 year old widow. She has 7 children and 3 of her children go to school. Fatuma is currently in the business of selling various items. She is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar, boxes of soap and other items to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, Fatuma hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar and boxes of soap to sell

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 48 year old man who lives in Lebanon with his wife and their four children. Since 1996, he has been selling fruits and vegetables in his truck. He is a mobile salesman. He says that he offers good quality merchandise depending on the season. He sells to his friends, neighbors and people from his region and its surroundings. Today, for the second time, he is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise and to do some construction on his house as well. Khaled has experience and is a hard working man. In the future, he plans on opening a grocery store where he will also keep on selling fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: San Miguel Group

texts.es:
“San Miguel” es un grupo de diez señoras  que asisten a sus reuniones en el Centro Focal “ Panamericana”,  este es su primer ciclo. Se agruparon por la necesidad de mejorar y ampliar sus negocios y acceder al préstamo y beneficiarse todas. 
Martha C. de 26 años casada, es vecina de la ciudad de El Alto, vive en la zona San Ancelmo hace 3 meses, ella tiene el negocio de artesanía (tejido de diferentes prendas de vestir), cuando termina sus productos los vende en la ciudad de La paz en la Garita de lunes a domingo hace 3 años y necesita el préstamo para comprar mercadería. Las demás integrantes tienen diversos negocios como tejido de mantas, venta de ropa, servicios de constructor, tienda de barrio, librería y otros. Todas desean el préstamo para mejorar sus negocios.

En la foto aparecen 11 personas en lugar de 10 porque una de ellas es pariente de una de las integrantes del grupo.
texts.en:
